name.text: 1.4.3.1 Addition and subtraction of algebraic fractions

questiontext.text:
Addition and subtraction of algebraic fractions

To add two algebraic fractions the lowest common denominator must be found first. This is the simplest algebraic expression that has the given denominators as its factors. All fractions must be written with this lowest common denominator. Their sum is found by adding the numerators and dividing the result by the lowest common denominator.

To subtract two fractions the process is similar. The fractions are written with the lowest common denominator. The difference is found by subtracting the numerators and dividing the result by the lowest common denominator.

Example

State the simplest expression which has \( x+1\) and \( x+4\) as its factors.

Solution

The simplest expression is \((x+1)(x+4).\) Note that both \(x+1\) and \(x+4\) are factors.

Example

State the simplest expression which has \( x-1\) and \( (x-1)^2\) as its factors.

Solution

The simplest expression is \( (x-1)^2.\) Clearly \( (x-1)^2 \) must be a factor of this expression. Also, because we can write \( (x-1)^2=(x-1)(x-1)\) it follows that \( x-1)\) is a factor too.

Example

Express as a single fraction \( \dfrac{3}{x+1}+\dfrac{2}{x+4} \)

Solution

The simplest expression which has both denominators as its factors is \( (x+1)(x+4).\)

This is the lowest common denominator. Both fractions must be written using this denominator.

Note that \( \dfrac{3}{x+1} \) is equivalent to \(\dfrac{3(x+4)}{(x+1)(x+4)}\) and \(\dfrac{2}{x+4}\) is equivalent to \(\dfrac{2(x+1)}{(x+1)(x+4)}. \)

Thus writing both fractions with the same denominator we have \[ \dfrac{3}{x+1}+\dfrac{2}{x+4} = \dfrac{3(x+4)}{(x+1)(x+4)} + \dfrac{2(x+1)}{(x+1)(x+4)}\]

The sum is found by adding the numerators and dividing the result by the lowest common denominator \[ \dfrac{3(x+4)}{(x+1)(x+4)} + \dfrac{2(x+1)}{(x+1)(x+4)} = \dfrac{3(x+4)+2(x+1)}{(x+1)(x+4)} = \dfrac{5x+14}{(x+1)(x+4)}\]


Key Point

Addition of two algebraic fractions

Step 1: Find the lowest common denominator

Step 2: Express each fraction with this denominator

Step 3: Add the numerators and divide the result by the lowest common denominator


Example

Express \( \dfrac{1}{x-1}+\dfrac{5}{(x-1)^2} \) as a single fraction.

Solution

The simplest expression which has both denominators as its factors is \( (x-1)^2.\) We write both fractions with this denominator.

\[ \dfrac{1}{x-1}+\dfrac{5}{(x-1)^2} = \dfrac{x-1}{(x-1)^2} + \dfrac{5}{(x-1)^2} = \dfrac{x-1+5}{(x-1)^2} = \dfrac{x+4}{(x-1)^2}\]

Example

Express \( \dfrac{5x}{7} - \dfrac{3x-4}{2} \) as a single fraction.

Solution

In this example both denominators are simply numbers. The lowest common denominator is \(14\), and both fractions are re-written with this denominator. Thus

\[ \dfrac{5x}{7} - \dfrac{3x-4}{2} = \dfrac{10x}{14} - \dfrac{7(3x-4)}{14} = \dfrac{10x-7(3x-4)}{14} = \dfrac{28-11x}{14}\]
